item.title: Tyson Fury vs Deontay Wilder: WBC sanctions rematch between heavyweights after controversial draw - The Independent
item.description:
Tyson Fury vs Deontay Wilder: WBC sanctions rematch between heavyweights after controversial draw  The Independent

A rematch between Tyson Fury and Deontay Wilder has been sanctioned by the World Boxing Council (WBC) following a championship fight in Los Angeles that ended in a contested draw. The WBC said in a statement that “a direct rematch has been approved” following a unanimous vote of its board of governors. “Wilder and Fury gave boxing one of the best fights in the heavyweight division in a long time, which has created tremendous popular demand for the fans to see a rematch,” it said. It continued: ”I wish to once again congratulate Deontay Wilder and Tyson Fury for their great battle inside the...

item.title: Tyson Fury moves step closer to Deontay Wilder rematch after WBC sanctions pair to fight again - The Telegraph
item.description:
Tyson Fury moves step closer to Deontay Wilder rematch after WBC sanctions pair to fight again  The Telegraph

The prospect of another fight between Tyson Fury and Deontay Wilder moved a step closer on Friday night when the WBC voted unanimously in favour of sanctioning a rematch. Wilder held onto his WBC belt after a controversial split-decision draw when the two men met in the ring last weekend. Both men suggested they would be keen on a rematch and the WBC have now officially sanctioned the fight. The decision means Wilder can now negotiate a second fight with Fury, despite having Dominic Breazeale as mandatory challenger. WBC president Mauricio Sulaiman said: “The World Boxing Council conducted ...

item.title: Deontay Wilder vs Tyson Fury: WBC vote in favour of sanctioning immediate rematch - talkSPORT
item.description:
Deontay Wilder vs Tyson Fury: WBC vote in favour of sanctioning immediate rematch  talkSPORT

The WBC have voted unanimously in favour of sanctioning an immediate rematch between Deontay Wilder and Tyson Fury. On Saturday night, the pair battled out a twelve-round epic which was controversially scored a draw by the three judges at ringside. Tyson Fury and Deontay Wilder’s fight was declared a draw However, now Wilder and Fury look set to go at it again, with the governing body giving their backing to a second fight – as well as both camps stating that they want a direct return next. WBC president Mauricio Sulaiman stated: “The World Boxing Council conducted a vote through the Board ...

item.title: Kell Brook set to become mandatory for dangerous, unbeaten champion Jarrett Hurd with win this weekend - talkSPORT
item.description:
Kell Brook set to become mandatory for dangerous, unbeaten champion Jarrett Hurd with win this weekend  talkSPORT

Kell Brook fights Australia’s Michael Zerafa on Saturday night in Sheffield, with a tougher foe potentially just around the corner. This weekend’s bout has now been upgraded to a WBA super-welterweight final eliminator, meaning the winner will become mandatory challenger for unified WBA and IBF world champion Jarrett Hurd. Kell Brook has not been in the ring since his win over Sergey Rabchenko in March The dangerous, 23-0 American is renowned for his relatively gargantuan size in the context of the super-welterweight division. This is because he has previously blown up to over 190lbs betwee...

item.title: Revealed: What referee Jack Reiss told Tyson Fury before he stunned the world by surviving Deontay Wilder knockdown - talkSPORT
item.description:
Revealed: What referee Jack Reiss told Tyson Fury before he stunned the world by surviving Deontay Wilder knockdown  talkSPORT

Tyson Fury somehow managed to survive THAT brutal combination by Deontay Wilder in the twelfth round of their fight last weekend in Los Angeles. Rising like WWE superstar The Undertaker off the canvas, Fury got off his back to the bewilderment of the watching world to win the remainder of the round and claim a controversial draw. Referee Jack Reiss counts over Tyson Fury However, new behind-the-scenes footage from the ‘Gypsy King’s’ dressing room explains why the fight was not called off as soon as he hit the deck. Referee Jack Reiss spoke to the Brit before the main event to ensure the smo...

item.title: Here's The Gargantuan Amount Of People Who Watched Deontay Wilder Vs. Tyson Fury On Illegal Streams - Forbes
item.description:
Here's The Gargantuan Amount Of People Who Watched Deontay Wilder Vs. Tyson Fury On Illegal Streams  Forbes

According to various media reports, the Deontay Wilder vs. Tyson Fury showdown compelled between 300,000-325,000 people to buy the fight on PPV. The people who watched the fight illegally, though, massively dwarfs that number. Tyson Fury, right, fought Deontay Wilder to a draw last Saturday. Millions apparently watched it illegally. (Photo by Philip Pacheco/Anadolu Agency/Getty Images) According to Muso, which studies the global piracy market, nearly 10 million people watched the heavyweight title fight on an illegal live stream that didn’t cost them a penny. That also means Showtime PPV di...

item.title: Tyson Fury overtakes Deontay Wilder in Ring Magazine heavyweight rankings following controversial draw - talkSPORT
item.description:
Tyson Fury overtakes Deontay Wilder in Ring Magazine heavyweight rankings following controversial draw  talkSPORT

Tyson Fury has leapfrogged Deontay Wilder in the Ring Magazine’s heavyweight rankings and is now rated second in the world by the historic boxing outlet. The two heavyweights’ recent title fight ended in a disputed draw, with many believing the Gypsy King should have got the decision – including every member of Ring’s ratings panel. Fury and Wilder both had their hands raised Unified champion Anthony Joshua remains top of the tree at present. Ring Magazine have their own independent ranking system, compiled by their editorial board and ratings panel. The institution also award a famous titl...

item.title: Floyd Mayweather savages ‘comatose’ Amir Khan in response to comments about Tenshin Nasukawa fight - talkSPORT
item.description:
Floyd Mayweather savages ‘comatose’ Amir Khan in response to comments about Tenshin Nasukawa fight  talkSPORT

Floyd Mayweather has fired back at Amir Khan in response to comments made about his upcoming exhibition with kickboxer Tenshin Nasukawa. The American great is set to return to the ring for a bizarre fight in Japan on New Year’s Eve, for which the ruleset has only just been announced. Floyd Mayweather hosted a press conference alongside Tenshin Nasukawa Khan has been heavily critical of the event, branding it a “joke” that is “hurting boxing,” and this has drawn a strong response from Money Mayweather. “Everybody’s got something to say about Floyd Mayweather,” the 41-year-old stated when ask...

item.title: Wilder sees missed opportunity in first viewing of Fury draw - The Associated Press
item.description:
Wilder sees missed opportunity in first viewing of Fury draw  The Associated Press

NEW YORK (AP) — Deontay Wilder fired his right hand out from his body, demonstrating the way he should have punched Tyson Fury. He was frustrated with the referee. Disappointed in Floyd Mayweather Jr. Angry with Showtime's scorer. Mostly, Wilder was mad at himself. Five days later, the WBC heavyweight champion was still bothered by the way he fought in his draw with Fury on Saturday night in Los Angeles. "Fury was everything I expected him to be. It's not what Fury did, it's what I didn't do," Wilder said Thursday. "You seen the best of Fury, you didn't see the best of me. "I wanted to end ...

item.title: Deontay Wilder, Over Steak and Fries, Relives His Biggest Fight - The New York Times
item.description:
Deontay Wilder, Over Steak and Fries, Relives His Biggest Fight  The New York Times

Watching two heavyweights pound each other on screen while one of them is sitting with you is a little strange. Like when the champion sees a scorecard showing himself down four points and erupts, screaming an epithet at the television to show his displeasure. On Thursday, five days after battling Tyson Fury to a wild and disputed draw, Deontay Wilder, the American heavyweight, sat down over a filet mignon and fries to watch the fight for the first time. Plenty of people felt that Wilder would have lost that fight — and his championship belt — had he not put Fury on the canvas twice in the ...

item.title: WBC will consider ordering Deontay Wilder vs Tyson Fury rematch, praise Fury and defend judges - talkSPORT
item.description:
WBC will consider ordering Deontay Wilder vs Tyson Fury rematch, praise Fury and defend judges  talkSPORT

The WBC have exclusively told talkSPORT.com that they will consider requests for a Deontay Wilder vs Tyson Fury rematch “accordingly and immediately.” Following the heavyweight fighters’ heavily disputed draw in LA on Saturday, the Brit’s promoter Frank Warren declared that he would write to the organisation and call for a return fight based on the belief that their man should have emerged victorious. Tyson Fury and Deontay Wilder’s fight was declared a draw However, Wilder is due to defend his WBC heavyweight title against long-time mandatory challenger Dominic Breazeale next – something t...

item.title: Deontay Wilder vs Tyson Fury fight on track to get over 300,000 buys on US pay-per-view market – reports - talkSPORT
item.description:
Deontay Wilder vs Tyson Fury fight on track to get over 300,000 buys on US pay-per-view market – reports  talkSPORT

Deontay Wilder and Tyson Fury produced one of the classic boxing matches in recent times as they fought to a draw in Los Angeles at the weekend. And they are on track to exceed expectations with the U.S pay-per-view market. The bout was controversially ruled a draw The heavyweight bout was broadcast on Showtime PPV and is expected surpass 300,000 buys, according to The Ring. That figure doesn’t include British PPV buys or digital purchases on platforms such as Playstation 4. The fight was also available in cinemas. If the estimate holds up then it would be a success for Showtime and PBC as ...

item.title: Wilder vs. Fury Reportedly Crossed Over 300,000 PPV Buys - International Business Times
item.description:
Wilder vs. Fury Reportedly Crossed Over 300,000 PPV Buys  International Business Times

Deontay Wilder's heavyweight title fight against Tyson Fury over the weekend is tracking to be a pay-per-view success. The two unbeaten heavyweights collided for Wilder's World Boxing Council title at the Staples Center on Saturday night in what was one of the fights of the year. The contest eventually went the distance as many believed Fury, who was taking part in just his third fight in over three years, had outclassed the American despite getting knocked down twice. However, the judges would controversially score the fight as a split decision draw, with one judge even scoring the fight 1...

item.title: Home turf: Tyson Fury calls for Deontay Wilder rematch at Old Trafford - RT
item.description:
Home turf: Tyson Fury calls for Deontay Wilder rematch at Old Trafford  RT

Tyson Fury wants to bring Deontay Wilder over to England for their WBC world heavyweight title rematch, with the home of the British fighter's beloved Manchester United, the famous Old Trafford stadium, his preferred venue. Fury went the distance with reigning WBC heavyweight champion Wilder in a thrilling title clash at the Staples Center in Los Angeles last weekend, but was left angry and frustrated when the judges at ringside rendered a split draw verdict. READ MORE: All square! Champ Wilder and plucky Fury scored a draw in heavyweight title fight (PHOTOS) Immediately after the scores we...

item.title: Dereck Chisora leaves Dillian Whyte bemused by promising to 'go through him like a laxative' - The Independent
item.description:
Dereck Chisora leaves Dillian Whyte bemused by promising to 'go through him like a laxative'  The Independent

Dereck Chisora has sparked what may be the strangest war of words yet ahead of his rematch with British heavyweight rival Dillian Whyte by promising to “go through him like laxatives”. The bizarre statement came as the two prepare to face-off once again later this month in a repeat of what was one of the fights of the year back in December 2016, which ended in a split-decision going in Whyte’s favour. As part of the bout, which takes place at the O2 in London on 22 December, the pair took part in the regular ‘Gloves are Off’ promotion show that accompanies events being shown on Sky Sports. ...

item.title: Tyson Fury confirms he wants Deontay Wilder rematch at Old Trafford in summer 2019 - The Independent
item.description:
Tyson Fury confirms he wants Deontay Wilder rematch at Old Trafford in summer 2019  The Independent

Tyson Fury has confirmed that he wants to rematch Deontay Wilder in the summer of 2019 at Old Trafford. At the post-fight press conference in the early hours of Sunday morning, Fury’s promoter Frank Warren said: “I’d love the rematch. I’d love to see it in the UK. We’d fill a football stadium up, Wembley, Arsenal, any of those big stadiums.” But being interviewed at half-time as Manchester United took on Arsenal at Old Trafford, Fury said that if the rematch happens in the UK, it will be taking place in his hometown of Manchester. Tyson Fury vs Deontay Wilder - in pictures - 35 show all Tys...

item.title: Deontay Wilder rips into heavyweight rival Anthony Joshua, hopes he gets knocked out - talkSPORT
item.description:
Deontay Wilder rips into heavyweight rival Anthony Joshua, hopes he gets knocked out  talkSPORT

Deontay Wilder said he hopes Anthony Joshua gets knocked out by one of his “second-tier” opponents in the near future. The American made his feelings clear when asked about his heavyweight rival, following his disputed draw with Tyson Fury on Saturday night. Wilder retained the belt, but was forced to settle for a controversial draw against Fury Negotiations for a fight between AJ and the Bronze Bomber broke down earlier this year, leading the WBC champion to his bout with Fury. However, the way talks collapsed has undoubtedly left a bitter taste. “I haven’t even thought about Joshua and th...

item.title: Tyson Fury vs Deontay Wilder: Referee Jack Reiss defends his decision to let fight continue, slamming ‘knuckleheads’ who claimed 10-second count was too long - talkSPORT
item.description:
Tyson Fury vs Deontay Wilder: Referee Jack Reiss defends his decision to let fight continue, slamming ‘knuckleheads’ who claimed 10-second count was too long  talkSPORT

Respected boxing referee Jack Reiss has defended his decision to let Tyson Fury continue after Deontay Wilder brutally knocked him down in the twelve round of their thrilling heavyweight title contest. Reiss has received worldwide praise for his handling of the incident, which could have resulted in the end of the fight on another day. Jack Reiss pictured during the 10-second count with Tyson Fury, following a brutal knockdown from Deontay Wilder The decision was justified as Fury, left, successfully got through the rest of the heavyweight showdown – which ended in a controversial draw Spea...

Tempers have flared and the aggression in the trash talk has been escalated. That can mean just one thing for Saturday’s WBC heavyweight championship fight; it means we’re getting close. Boxers Deontay Wilder, left, and Tyson Fury exchange words as they face each other at a news conference in Los Angeles, Wednesday, Nov. 28, 2018. item.title: Adonis Stevenson update: Boxer given good chance of survival, but long-term consequences likely - talkSPORT
item.description:
Adonis Stevenson update: Boxer given good chance of survival, but long-term consequences likely  talkSPORT

Adonis Stevenson has been given a “good chance” of survival following his knockout defeat to Oleksandr Gvozdyk on Saturday night. The 41-year-old’s doctors held a press conference and issued an in-depth statement on Wednesday, declaring that he will likely have to deal with long-term consequences as a result of his injuries. Adonis Stevenson was knocked out by Oleksandr Gvozdyk in the eleventh round Stevenson suffered a severe traumatic brain injury after reportedly collapsing back in his dressing room after the fight. The Canadian underwent surgery later that night and has remained in an i...

item.title: Tyson Fury confirms he wants Deontay Wilder rematch to take place at Manchester United’s Old Trafford stadium - talkSPORT
item.description:
Tyson Fury confirms he wants Deontay Wilder rematch to take place at Manchester United’s Old Trafford stadium  talkSPORT

Tyson Fury has confirmed he wants to fight Deontay Wilder at Old Trafford in the summer of 2019. The ‘Gypsy King’ was controversially denied the chance to bring home the WBC heavyweight title after his clash at the Staples Center in Los Angeles, with the fight somehow being scored a draw. Fury confirmed he wants to fight Deontay Wilder at Old Trafford in the summer of 2019 Despite dominating much of the fight, Fury was knocked down twice by the ‘Bronze Bomber’. However, he showed no signs of ring rust after his extended absence from the ring and immediately called for a second crack at the ...

item.title: Tyson Fury casts some unexpected light from the darkest of places - The Guardian
item.description:
Tyson Fury casts some unexpected light from the darkest of places  The Guardian

In 1990 the poet Robert Bly wrote a runaway American bestseller called Iron John: A Book About Men. Iron John was about the weird, mystical power of the “deep male”. It became a key text in something called the Mythopoetic Men’s Movement, a shared urge for men to retreat into the woods, bare their woad-smeared chests and generally nurture their inner scowling, bearded masculinity. Naturally this went down well with 1990s American men, who were delighted to discover they were in fact reservoirs of vibrant male “Zeus power” (High five! Brewskis!). But Blyism wasn’t about ruling the boardroom,...

item.title: Tyson Fury wants Deontay Wilder rematch at Old Trafford - The Telegraph
item.description:
Tyson Fury wants Deontay Wilder rematch at Old Trafford  The Telegraph

Tyson Fury has hinted he would like a potential rematch with Deontay Wilder to take place at Old Trafford. The 30-year-old drew with Wilder in Los Angeles on Saturday in his bid to win the WBC heavyweight title from the American. Manchester-born Fury was in attendance at Old Trafford as Manchester United drew 2-2 with Arsenal on Wednesday in the Premier League. Speaking to BT Sport, he said: "Frank Warren (his promoter) said Arsenal but I said 'No, let's have it at Old Trafford'. Hopefully we can have it here in the summer." Fury was denied one of the greatest comebacks in boxing history af...

item.title: Dillian Whyte vs Dereck Chisora: When is it, fight date, undercard, where to watch, prediction, odds and more - The Independent
item.description:
Dillian Whyte vs Dereck Chisora: When is it, fight date, undercard, where to watch, prediction, odds and more  The Independent

Just 30 days remain until Dillian Whyte and Dereck Chisora meet for their hotly anticipated rematch at the O2 on 22 December on Sky Sports Box Office. Whyte edged the pair’s first grudge match in December 2016 by razor-tight split decision with many protesting that Chisora was the rightful victor. Eddie Hearn was hoping to stage the rematch in 2017 but Chisora succumbed to a drab points defeat to Agit Kabayel for the European Title in Monaco which scuppered those plans. Whyte meanwhile embarked on a strong run of form and has surged up the heavyweight rankings with successive wins against R...

item.title: Wilder remains WBC heavyweight champion after draw with Fury - Al Jazeera English
item.description:
Wilder remains WBC heavyweight champion after draw with Fury  Al Jazeera English

Heavyweight boxers Deontay Wilder and Tyson Fury finished their match for the WBC heavyweight championship with a split draw decision on Sunday. Wilder, the undefeated WBC champion retained his title after squaring off against undefeated challenger and former WBA, WBO, IBO, and unofficial lineal champion Fury, in front of almost 18,000 people at the Staples Center in Los Angeles. After twelve rounds, the judges scored the match 115-111 for Wilder, 114-110 for Fury and 113-113, leading to a split draw decision. Following the decision, both men said they thought they did enough to eke out the...

item.title: Tyson Fury has beaten his demons to become a champion for mental health - The Guardian
item.description:
Tyson Fury has beaten his demons to become a champion for mental health  The Guardian

As a psychiatrist whose job is to preserve healthy minds, it feels a little unusual to be championing a mental health advocate who punches people in the head for a job. But that’s where I find myself with Tyson Fury. On Sunday, having set my alarm for silly o’clock in the morning, I got up, boiled the kettle and sat down to watch two grown men try to knock each other into states of unconsciousness; the kind I’d always been taught to avoid at medical school. I’m not really a fan of boxing. Besides the risk of chronic traumatic encephalopathy induced by a head injury (“punch-drunk syndrome”),...

item.title: Deontay Wilder insists he should have won Tyson Fury fight, posts ‘video proof’ Brit did not beat ten count - talkSPORT
item.description:
Deontay Wilder insists he should have won Tyson Fury fight, posts ‘video proof’ Brit did not beat ten count  talkSPORT

Deontay Wilder has posted a video which he claims proves Tyson Fury did not beat the count in the 12th round of their epic fight. The unbeaten pair’s WBC heavyweight title bout in Los Angeles on Saturday night ended in a controversial draw. Fury was sent crashing to the canvas by an almighty two-punch combination Fury was sent to the canvas twice by Wilder but still believed he won the fight Fury was floored twice and looked finished in the the final round when Wilder sent him crashing to the canvas, but his camp – and the majority of boxing fans – were insistent he should have won having b...

item.title: Kell Brook claims Amir Khan has ‘run off’ to fight Terence Crawford instead of him and has ‘let the public down’ - talkSPORT
item.description:
Kell Brook claims Amir Khan has ‘run off’ to fight Terence Crawford instead of him and has ‘let the public down’  talkSPORT

Kell Brook has slammed his long-time nemesis Amir Khan after news emerged that he is now pursuing a bout with Terence Crawford. The British pair have spent the year being lined up to finally meet by mutual promoter Eddie Hearn, however Khan has now revealed alternative plans. Amir Khan and Kell Brook recently met ringside at Oleksandr Usyk vs Tony Bellew The Bolton man stated on Monday that he is instead looking at a reported $5million offer to face WBO welterweight champion – and pound-for-pound star – Terence Crawford on March 23 in New York. This comes as a massive disappointment to Broo...

item.title: After another victory, Jarrett Hurd sets his eyes on a home bout in D.C., Jermell Charlo and beyond - The Washington Post
item.description:
After another victory, Jarrett Hurd sets his eyes on a home bout in D.C., Jermell Charlo and beyond  The Washington Post

Jarrett Hurd celebrates his win against Jason Welborn in Los Angeles. (Andrew Couldridge/Reuters)Action Images Via Reuters LOS ANGELES – Shortly after the bell rang to usher in the fourth round, lightly-regarded Jason Welborn of Britain brought the Staples Center crowd of 17,698 to their feet by launching a furious rally, and landing several power punches on Jarrett Hurd. And that was when Hurd – the International Boxing Federation, International Boxing Organization and World Boxing Association junior middleweight champion – decided to get to work. “I got caught on the ropes, and got caught...

item.title: Tyson Fury’s brother Tommy reveals how much of an inspiration heavyweight boxer has been in and out of the ring - talkSPORT
item.description:
Tyson Fury’s brother Tommy reveals how much of an inspiration heavyweight boxer has been in and out of the ring  talkSPORT

Tommy Fury believes that brother Tyson “is the best heavyweight there has ever been” as he looks to follow in his footsteps when he makes his professional debut later this month. Light-heavyweight contender Fury is due to face Latvian Jevgenijs Andrejevs (10-102-3) on December 22 at the Manchester Arena. Tommy Fury is gearing up for his professional debut later this month Tommy, who is trained by boxing legend Ricky Hatton, says his brother Tyson has been an inspiration to him Tyson was denied one of the greatest comebacks in sporting history after his WBC world heavyweight title bout with ...

item.title: Tyson Fury vs Deontay Wilder: Pay-per-view sales reveal fight was the biggest US heavyweight bout in 15 years - The Independent
item.description:
Tyson Fury vs Deontay Wilder: Pay-per-view sales reveal fight was the biggest US heavyweight bout in 15 years  The Independent

Tyson Fury and Deontay Wilder’s WBC title fight was the biggest heavyweight boxing event in the US for 15 years. The fight ended in a controversial draw with many suggesting that Fury was unfortunate not to get a unanimous points decision, although Wilder believes he should have won after Fury’s count began late when he was knocked down in the final round. The number of pay-per-view buys stateside is set to surpass 300,000, although this reported figure does not contain numbers from the UK sales, or those that watched it on Playstations or in cinemas. Tyson Fury vs Deontay Wilder - in pictu...

item.title: Tyson Fury’s sexist and homophobic remarks would make him the most undeserving BBC Sports Personality of the Year ever - The Independent
item.description:
Tyson Fury’s sexist and homophobic remarks would make him the most undeserving BBC Sports Personality of the Year ever  The Independent

The dust had barely settled on his WBC heavyweight title showdown with Deontay Wilder when the calls came for Tyson Fury to be named the BBC Sports Personality of the Year in the early hours of Sunday morning. He had, after all, not only come back from the brink during the fight itself after going down hard in the final round, but had overcome numerous personal hurdles just to get into the ring against the undefeated Wilder. This time last year, towards the end of his two-and-a-half-year break from the sport, Fury claims he weighed 400lbs – around 150lbs more than he did on Sunday. During h...

item.title: Deontay Wilder, Tyson Fury fight to a split draw; Wilder retains title - The Washington Post
item.description:

Tyson Fury taunts Deontay Wilder during weigh-in at Los Angeles Convention Center on Friday. Wilder will attempt to defend his WBC heavyweight title Saturday at Staples Center. (Harry How/Getty Images)Getty Images Decision: Deontay Wilder retains his World Boxing Council heavyweight championship by split decision draw with Tyson Fury. And here are the cards: 115-111 Wilder 114-112 Fury 113-113 It’s a split decision draw. The heavyweight renaissance continues. Boxing’s glamour division, plagued for years by the dominant and largely humdrum title reign of Wladmir Klistchko, has produced sever...

item.title: Top ten heavyweights in boxing ranked following Deontay Wilder vs Tyson Fury draw, featuring Anthony Joshua and Dillian Whyte - talkSPORT
item.description:
Top ten heavyweights in boxing ranked following Deontay Wilder vs Tyson Fury draw, featuring Anthony Joshua and Dillian Whyte  talkSPORT

On Saturday night, Tyson Fury shook up boxing’s heavyweight division and not for the first time. After initially displacing long-reigning ruler Wladimir Klitschko in 2015, the Gypsy King took two-and-a-half years out of the ring, but is now well and truly back in the mix having gone toe-to-toe with WBC champion Deontay Wilder. Tyson Fury and Deontay Wilder’s fight was declared a draw As far as most observers (including us) could see, Fury defeated Wilder by a score of around 115:111 or 114:112 and should now be a two-time heavyweight world champion. item.title: Amir Khan close to agreeing sensational deal to fight Terence Crawford, admitting Kell Brook fight ‘is always going to be there’ - talkSPORT
item.description:
Amir Khan close to agreeing sensational deal to fight Terence Crawford, admitting Kell Brook fight ‘is always going to be there’  talkSPORT

Amir Khan is close to sealing a deal to sign pound-for-pound great Terence Crawford in a stunning turn of events. The 31-year-old still wants to fight domestic rival Kell Brook, but admitted the chance to face one of the best in the world in 2019 was ‘amazing’. Khan is set to challenge pound-for-pound king Terence Crawford After making his comeback under promoter Eddie Hearn in April, the 31-year-old seemed destined to finally face Brook in a fight which Hearn believed the British public deserves. However, a fight in America against three-time world champion and current WBO welterweight kin...

item.title: Jarrett Hurd’s health no longer in doubt heading into junior middleweight title defense - The Washington Post
item.description:
Jarrett Hurd’s health no longer in doubt heading into junior middleweight title defense  The Washington Post

Hidden amid the artwork tattooed around his upper arm and chest area, the scar on Jarrett Hurd’s left shoulder is almost unnoticeable except upon close examination. The Accokeek boxer enjoys pointing it out, though, discussing how it got there, with the remnants from an arthroscopic procedure for a torn rotator cuff serving as a reminder of the most memorable night in his professional life nearly seven months ago. Even with that damaged shoulder that wouldn’t be surgically repaired for another six weeks, Hurd confidently stepped into the ring to face seasoned veteran Erislandy Lara on April...

Tyson Fury is looking to upset the odds once again and take the WBC heavyweight belt from Deontay Wilder. The Gypsy King spent two-and-a-half years away from boxing before making his return to the ring this year following well-documented issues in his private life. Tyson Fury is back and out to shock the world How do I stream Deontay Wilder vs Tyson Fury live online? Tyson Fury vs Deontay Wilder is exclusively live on BT Sport Box Office, at a cost of £19.95 On you purchase the fight you can live stream it on the BT Sport Box Office App or on your PC through the BT Player. item.title: Wilder hoping for a rematch with Fury 'ASAP' - The Associated Press
item.description:
Wilder hoping for a rematch with Fury 'ASAP'  The Associated Press

MONTGOMERY, Ala. (AP) — WBC heavyweight champion Deontay Wilder says he wants a rematch with Tyson Fury "ASAP." Wilder said in a conference call Tuesday that he's "ready and willing to give Tyson Fury the opportunity ASAP." The two heavyweights fought to a split-decision draw Saturday night in Los Angeles in one of the bigger heavyweight bouts in America in years. "I'm ready whenever he's ready," Wilder said. "I'm ready whenever he's ready to do it. I'm ready to give the fans what they want to see and end this talk once and for all." Afterward, the British challenger said the two would "100...

item.title: Frank Warren demands Eddie Hearn make a Anthony Joshua vs Tyson Fury super-fight happen - talkSPORT
item.description:
Frank Warren demands Eddie Hearn make a Anthony Joshua vs Tyson Fury super-fight happen  talkSPORT

Frank Warren, has demanded Anthony Joshua face Tyson Fury in the biggest fight in British boxing history. Both Fury and Joshua have talked up the bout following the Gypsy King’s controversial draw with Deontay Wilder in their LA title fight, prompting the promoter to speak out about what it would take to make the match happen. Tyson Fury signed with Frank Warren early in 2018 “If you did a poll now with the fans for Anthony Joshua’s next fight… what do you think would be top of the pops there?” Warren asked on the Alan Brazil Sports Breakfast on talkSPORT. “I’m quite sure [they want] to see...

item.title: Deontay Wilder reveals he broke his arm and had surgery prior to Tyson Fury fight - talkSPORT
item.description:
Deontay Wilder reveals he broke his arm and had surgery prior to Tyson Fury fight  talkSPORT

Deontay Wilder has revealed he suffered a broken arm just 12 weeks before starting camp for his fight with Tyson Fury. Saturday’s bout ended in a disputed draw as the Brit recovered from two knockdowns to seemingly box his way to a points victory, however the three judges were split on the result. Deontay Wilder struggled to find a home for his big right hand for most of the night Throughout the bout, Fury appeared to be making his opponent miss with multiple winging right hands, however the American has now offered his reasoning as to why this happened. “Twelve weeks before camp I broke my...
